course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Contemporary China: Continuity and Change
course.description: This course introduces students to the major developments and changes in China since 1949 from a multidisciplinary social science perspective. It reviews the transformative and developmental strategies in the spheres of politics, economics, society and external relations during that historical epoch. It critically examines change and continuity over three periods, namely 1949-1977 or the Mao years, 1978-1989, the earlier reform and open-up years, and 1989-present, the post-Tiananmen years.

reviews.title: Contemporary China
reviews.comment_content: First three weeks are about history of modern China from 1911 revolution to contemporary. Then the topics will mainly turn to the economics, politics and society of contemporary China. Thought most content are not deep enough, from my point of view, this is course is quite a good choice for those without common sense about China. This course will give you a basic outline of contemporary China. If you want deeper insight, you'd better take more courses or do more reading.

p.s. Many mainland students with strong knowledge about China will also take this course. So, take care.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is quite light. One midterm and one final only. As the examination is openbook, you don't have to remember much. Just remember to take notes during the class, do some review before examination and you will get a good grade. Although it's pretty hard to concentrate for 2 hours, I suggest you better do so since it's almost the only "workload".

However, you must pay attention in the lectures to avoid missing the details mentioned by the prof. Also, if you plan to skip many lessons, DO NOT choose this class since you may really get a 'F'... All in all, this is a great course (in terms of grading) and you just need to focus in the lectures, jot down all the notes and you will very likely get a good grade. ;)

reviews.comment_content:
The course is mainly focused on the reformation policies of China during the 80-90s. A lot of historical context regarding the events and turmoil during Mao's reign is covered.

Some of the core ideas discussed:
- Political structure of CCP
- Evolution of the economic system
- Household registration system (戶口制度)
    -> Rural / urban divide and internal migration
- Social organisations
    -> Work units (單位), people's communes (人民公社), etc.
- Social stratification
- Education inequality
- Population control

There are no official prerequisites, but having a basic understanding of China and (perhaps) a bit of knowledge in economics would help.

There are additional readings every week which is part of the exam syllabus, in the form of textbook excerpts and academic papers. I recommend reading the papers (especially those authored by the lecturer) as those are more likely to appear in the exams.

However, he stammers a lot which makes it slightly difficult to pay full attention to what he is talking about. Another problem is that his lectures overrun a lot - sometimes by 20 min or more.

This may seem obvious but expect a lot of unfamiliar Chinese / CCP phrases and slogans in the lecture notes.

TAs are quite helpful and give hints on how to prepare for the exams.
reviews.comment_grading:

15% Attendance / participation
40% Midterm
45% Final

Both midterm and final are conducted over Zoom this semester. Students can refer to all of the notes, readings and tutorial slides during the exam.

Final: Mean 34.7/45, SD 5.06

I scored +1.2 SD for midterm, +0.4 SD for final, got A- in the end. Not bad considering that I have no prior knowledge about the topic whatsoever.
reviews.comment_workload:
Extremely light workload, at least for this semester. Open-book exams with MC questions only. No homework / projects / quizzes of any sort. This is pretty much the only reason I chose this course to fulfill the SA-SSC requirement.

Attendance will be taken so remember to attend all tutorial sessions.

He will be mentioning key points during the lectures that you have to write down and remember for the midterm and final
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is the same for everyone. Multiple choice questions. Though, for a history exam, I would much prefer to write essays.. I do not understand why a history examination requires multiple choice answers. Also the multiple choice answers are quite difficult as none of the answers are totally wrong. He likes to put all correct answers but for you to pick out the best answer for the question, which is super annoying.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is
midterm
final
and you must attend the tutorials

reviews.author: TL96
reviews.title: Interesting course, good instructor
reviews.comment_content: Introductory course about Chinese development in the pre and especially post-Mao era. The professor includes both qualitative and quantitative economic and sociological data on slides, and assesses the historical progression of China through social, political, economic lenses.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is lecture-based, with one lecture per week, and tutorials every two weeks. Tutorials revolve around discussion of a video clip that is around 60 minutes. The instructor has good english and likes to deviate from what is seen on the slides, he does not read off the slides. Attendance is important in order to gain additional information and analysis of slide content before the exam.
reviews.comment_grading: All-multiple choice and open-book midterm and final. Participation grades are not difficult to get in tutorials, discussion topics are handed out in the beginning and you have time to think of how to respond. Time for exams is quite short, though the number of questions on the midterm and final is also low.
reviews.comment_workload: Not too heavy, open-book exam so important to review slides to know where to find information, but readings on reserve in library are optional but very useful to understanding course modules.

reviews.author: day
reviews.title: Very good
reviews.comment_content: It talks about Contemporary China, which was the period after 1949. The things are very easy to understand and follow if you have very basic knowledge about China or have studied liberal studies about modern china in high school. It does not really matter whether you have studied history in high school or not because the professor explains things in a very detailed way that even me who have no history background can understand all the stuff.
reviews.comment_teaching: I would say the professor is one of my favorite professors in UST. You can feel his passion in teaching that he is well-prepared. He can speak very fluently and with good pronunciation despite the fact that he comes from the mainland.  The only thing that may not be very good to most students is that his tone is so flat that many may easily fall asleep.
reviews.comment_grading: It is really good when comparing the workload and the final results. To be honest, listen to what he said in the lessons and have a quick look at the lecture notes just before the exam is good enough already. The exam questions are not very tricky and most importantly is an open book one! There are 25 questions in mid-term which last for one hour and 40 questions in the final exam which last for 2 hours. You can easily get a B range in this course, which may be better than those courses that the average score is around C+.
reviews.comment_workload: 0 workload, just need to revise before the mid-term and final exam. Really good!

reviews.author: Hellohihima
reviews.title: Light workload
reviews.comment_content: The content is mainly about the history,culture after the PRC rules China. I think it is easy to handle.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. is very nice as he was always willing to answer students' questions. However, I think it is a bit boring.
reviews.comment_grading: I think it is quite good, I didn't listen much to his lectures, but only rely on the notes and I finally got a B.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload, only mid term and final, and both open book. However, you should attend every lectures as attendance is counted.

reviews.author: jaehee
reviews.comment_content: The content of the class is very interesting. I learned a lot through this course and the professor seems very passionate about the materials covered in the class.
reviews.comment_teaching: The pace can be too quick at first but once the student adapts and discovers an efficient way to take notes during the lectures, exams become easier as the tests are open-note.
reviews.comment_grading: It depends on how well the student takes notes during lectures and how focused he/she is during class.
reviews.comment_workload: No out of work assignment but it is recommended to review your notes often.

reviews.author: ykl
reviews.comment_teaching: It's boring. The professor basically reads out what was on the ppt.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is really good. I got an A- even though I skipped almost 5 classes. For mid-term, out of 25 questions I got 23. And for final exam, I got 35 out of 40. The catch is I didn't even go to class or study because it's an open book exam.
reviews.comment_workload: Attendance is 10%. But other than that there are only two open book exams. You will also gain extra points if you ask or answer questions during lectures or tutorials. You also do not have to do any readings.

reviews.author: lucky_francis
reviews.title: good grade but quite heavy workload
reviews.comment_content: major developments and changes in China since 1949 from a multidisciplinary social science perspective. Topics include the background and structure of the State and the Government, Socialist Economy and Economic Reform, Rural-Urban Divide, The Work Unit System etc. For those who takes DSE has learnt some concepts in the subject of liberal studies.
reviews.comment_teaching: Each lecture lasts for 1 hour and 50 minutes, one lecture each week. The teaching is quite boring, just go through the PPT with 90% words and 10% graphic stuffs. You don't need to participate actively in class as no participating cards are given but there are some pop-quiz in random lectures which take attendance, and your correct answers are counted in this area. Tutorial classes are even more interesting than the lectures where videos or documentary films of modern of China is played and it lasts for almost a hour. After that, there are some discussions on that videos, just easy stuffs, and attendance is counted in tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
I have scored above mean 0.5 sd in both the mid-term examination as well as the final examination which gives me B+ finally.

Course assessment :
Participation 15%
Mid-term exam 35%
Final exam 35%
Term paper 15%
reviews.comment_workload: Best part of the project in this course is individual essay which accounts for 15%. You may choose any topics learnt in lectures and to discover it deeply. For mid term and final examination, it is all bout memorizing the PPT, most of the questions come from the PPT. I don't recommend you just studying all the things in the study break, it will be hard to memorize all stuffs. It is reminded that it is a closed-book examination, while the lecture for another professor is opened-book examination.

reviews.author: HELLO:)
reviews.title: Good grade+low workload choice
reviews.comment_content:
As a pre-reg course for GCS Year 1 student
Covered different topics of China, such as political, economic, social, cultural changes and continuities
each topic cover from 1949 to present
quite like a beginning course to learn more about China as it cover quite many facts

Professor Lin can provide a comprehensive teaching in the class as he provides many data to support his view
He and the TA are willing to answer our inquiries  
You need to pay attention in class as some of the contents tested were    not in the ppt but mentioned orally
If you want a good grade, jot down what he said!
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term     35%
Final            50%
Attendance 10%
(sign-in after class and tutorial sessions)
Participation 5%
(required to raise at least 3 times to get)

Many people got A grade and B grade
reviews.comment_workload:

only attend the tutorial sessions and class regularly will do
You can also answer some questions in the tutorial sessions to get the participation mark

reviews.author: Wingo
reviews.comment_content: The course is about the social change in China starting the 1950 to modern stage. I think the content is quite similar to the Modern China, a module in Liberal Studies in HKDSE. If you are interested in China social policies and development, this course is not difficult to you.
reviews.comment_teaching: The course consists of lectures and tutorials. I think the teaching style is unique from other courses. You can feel free to ask question and interact with lecturers. It is helpful when you take all the courses though attendance and participation are included in grading.
reviews.comment_grading: The assessment includes attendance, participation, midterm and final.
reviews.comment_workload: Overall, the workload is acceptable. You can memorise the teaching notes one to two days before the exams.

reviews.author: yuiyui

reviews.author: Candy_cc
reviews.comment_content: It is about some Chinese history and development. The content ranges from economic to social and political changes of China.

reviews.author: vault34overseer

reviews.author: legendarychriz

If students need to choose majors, this course may not be the best choice for you.

If you want to have good grades in this course, study hard.
